verses.text: Jesus got into a boat, crossed over, and came to His own city.
verses.comment: His own city refers to Capernaum, which served as Jesus' ministry base. The parallel accounts in Mark and Luke confirm this chronology.

verses.text: And behold, they brought to Him a paralytic lying on a bed. When Jesus saw their faith, He said to the paralytic, 'Take courage, son; your sins are forgiven.'
verses.comment: Jesus addresses the man's sins before his physical ailment, teaching that spiritual healing is even more important than physical. Only God can forgive sins (see Ps. 32:1-2), which points to the divinity of Christ.

verses.text: And, behold, some of the scribes said to themselves, 'This man is blaspheming.'
verses.comment: The scribes recognized that forgiving sins was a divine prerogative. Their accusation reveals their understanding of the gravity of Jesus' claim.

verses.text: But Jesus, knowing their thoughts, said, 'Why do you think evil in your hearts?'
verses.comment: Jesus demonstrates His divine knowledge by reading hearts, a trait attributed to God alone (see 1 Kings 8:39).

verses.text: 'For which is easier, to say, ‘Your sins are forgiven,’ or to say, ‘Get up and walk’?'
verses.comment: Jesus uses their logic to point out that only God, who can heal the body, can also forgive sins. Both deeds reveal divine authority.

verses.text: 'But so that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins,' He said to the paralytic, 'Rise, pick up your bed and go to your house.'
verses.comment: The title 'Son of Man' (Dan. 7:13-14) refers to the divine-human figure with authority over all nations. Jesus' act of healing proves His power to forgive sins and hints at a unique priestly ministry.

verses.text: And he rose and went away to his house.
verses.comment: Immediate healing publicly confirms Jesus' divine claim to forgive sins, validating His spiritual and earthly mission.

verses.text: But when the crowds saw this, they were afraid and glorified God, who had given such authority to men.
verses.comment: The crowd recognizes divine authority at work in Jesus. The phrase 'to men' could foreshadow God's intention to share His ministry and authority with human representatives.

verses.text: As Jesus passed on from there, He saw a man named Matthew sitting at the tax collector's booth and He said to him, 'Follow Me.' And he rose and followed Him.
verses.comment: The call of Matthew demonstrates Jesus' initiative in choosing unlikely followers. Matthew responds immediately—a picture of the transformative call to discipleship.

verses.text: As Jesus was dining in the house, many tax collectors and sinners came and were eating with Jesus and His disciples.
verses.comment: Jesus’ table fellowship with sinners shows His mission is to seek and save the lost, demonstrating openness and mercy.

verses.text: When the Pharisees saw this, they said to His disciples, 'Why does your Teacher eat with tax collectors and sinners?'
verses.comment: Table fellowship implied acceptance and a willingness to engage with those outside traditional boundaries. See how Jesus upends religious expectations.

verses.text: When Jesus heard this, He said, 'Those who are well have no need of a physician, but those who are sick.'
verses.comment: Jesus uses a medical analogy: He comes for sinners, not the self-righteous. True spiritual healing requires acknowledging one’s need.

verses.text: 'But go and learn what this means: ‘I desire mercy, and not sacrifice.’ For I did not come to call the righteous, but sinners.'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Hosea 6:6. He prioritizes interior conversion over ritual practices alone—a call to authentic repentance and merciful love.

verses.text: Then the disciples of John came to Him, saying, 'Why do we and the Pharisees fast often, but Your disciples do not fast?'
verses.comment: John’s disciples are observing Jewish fasting customs. They question Jesus' new approach. Fasting will take on renewed meaning later in Christian tradition.

verses.text: And Jesus said to them, 'Can the friends of the bridegroom mourn as long as the bridegroom is with them? But the days will come when the bridegroom is taken away from them, and then they will fast.'
verses.comment: Jesus identifies Himself as the bridegroom, a messianic title from the Old Testament (Isa. 62:5). He points to His coming departure—His Passion. The practice of fasting will return as a means of spiritual preparation after His ascension.

verses.text: 'No one puts a piece of unshrunk cloth on an old garment; for the patch pulls away from the garment, and the tear becomes worse.'
verses.comment: Jesus explains that His new covenant is not simply a patch on old religious customs. It represents an entirely new reality.

verses.text: 'Nor do people put new wine into old wineskins: if they do, the skins burst, the wine is spilled, and the skins are destroyed; but new wine is put into fresh wineskins, and both are preserved.'
verses.comment: The new wine symbolizes the life and power of grace in the new covenant—requiring new structures and receptivity. This anticipates the need for both visible and spiritual renewal in the practice of faith.

verses.text: While He was saying these things to them, behold, a ruler came and knelt before Him, saying, 'My daughter has just died, but come and lay Your hand on her, and she will live.'
verses.comment: The ruler’s act of kneeling shows faith in Jesus’ divine authority over life and death.

verses.text: And Jesus rose and followed him, and so did His disciples.
verses.comment: The disciples follow Jesus, modeling the call to participate in His ministry and miraculous works.

verses.text: And behold, a woman who had suffered from a discharge of blood for twelve years came up behind Him and touched the fringe of His garment.
verses.comment: Touching the fringe of Jesus' garment (see Num. 15:38-39) implies faith in both the holiness of Jesus and in the sanctifying power given physical expression.

verses.text: For she said to herself, 'If only I touch His garment, I will be healed.'
verses.comment: Her statement reveals the power of faith and the effectiveness of humble acts in reaching the grace that Jesus mediates.

verses.text: But Jesus turned around, and seeing her, He said, 'Take courage, daughter; your faith has made you well.' And the woman was made well from that hour.
verses.comment: Jesus recognizes faith as the means by which healing and salvation are received. He calls her 'daughter,' emphasizing both spiritual and familial restoration.

verses.text: When Jesus came to the ruler’s house and saw the flute players and the crowd making a commotion,
verses.comment: Flute players were hired for mourning the dead. Jesus enters into our suffering, contrasting worldly mourning with divine action.

verses.text: He said, 'Go away; for the girl is not dead but sleeping.' And they laughed at Him.
verses.comment: Jesus refers to death as sleep, showing He has power to awaken and restore life. The crowd’s laughter shows their lack of faith.

verses.text: But when the crowd had been sent out, He went in and took her by the hand, and the girl arose.
verses.comment: Taking her hand, Jesus raises her, as the prophets once did. His gesture implies the power of touch, sacramental acts, and the reality of bodily resurrection, a key Christian hope.

verses.text: And this report spread throughout all that land.
verses.comment: News of Jesus’ miracles immediately spreads, increasing His fame and drawing more people to Him.

verses.text: As Jesus was leaving, two blind men followed Him, calling out, 'Have mercy on us, Son of David!'
verses.comment: Calling Jesus 'Son of David' recognizes Him as the promised Messiah (see 2 Sam. 7:12-16). The blind men seek mercy, the root of all spiritual healing.

verses.text: When He had entered the house, the blind men came to Him. Jesus said to them, 'Do you believe that I am able to do this?' They replied, 'Yes, Lord.'
verses.comment: Faith is again emphasized as the condition for receiving God's grace. The blind men affirm Jesus’ Lordship.

verses.text: Then He touched their eyes, saying, 'According to your faith, let it be done to you.'
verses.comment: The touch of Jesus and His words bring about healing, illustrating both the mystery of grace and cooperation with faith.

verses.text: And their eyes were opened. Jesus sternly warned them, saying, 'See that no one knows about this.'
verses.comment: The 'Messianic Secret'—Jesus postpones public acclaim until His mission is fully revealed. There is a time for public proclamation, and a time for silence.

verses.text: But they went out and spread the news about Him throughout all that land.
verses.comment: Despite Jesus’ instruction, the healed cannot contain their joy. Their witness foreshadows how the good news will be spread by those transformed by Christ.

verses.text: As they were going out, behold, a mute man who was demon-possessed was brought to Him.
verses.comment: The healing of the demon-possessed mute demonstrates Jesus’ authority over both spiritual evils and physical afflictions.

verses.text: And when the demon had been cast out, the mute man spoke. The crowds were amazed, saying, 'Nothing like this has ever been seen in Israel.'
verses.comment: Healing the mute fulfills messianic prophecy (Isa. 35:5-6), marking Jesus as the one who establishes the kingdom of God on earth.

verses.text: But the Pharisees said, 'He casts out demons by the ruler of demons.'
verses.comment: The Pharisees accuse Jesus of working by demonic power, a charge He later refutes as being illogical and blasphemous. This passage warns against closing one’s heart to God’s action.

verses.text: Jesus went through all the cities and villages, teaching in their synagogues, proclaiming the gospel of the kingdom, and healing every disease and every affliction.
verses.comment: Jesus combines preaching, teaching, and healing—a model for the holistic ministry of the Church throughout history.

verses.text: When He saw the crowds, He had compassion on them, because they were harassed and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd.
verses.comment: Jesus fulfills the divine role of shepherd (Num. 27:17; Ezek. 34:5)—guiding and caring for the flock. This prepares the way for leaders with spiritual authority over God's people.

verses.text: Then He said to His disciples, 'The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few.'
verses.comment: Jesus refers to the coming conversion of many souls, underscoring the importance of those who are called and sent out in His name.

verses.text: 'Therefore pray earnestly to the Lord of the harvest to send out laborers into His harvest.'
verses.comment: Jesus teaches His disciples to pray for more workers, indicating that God will continually call and commission others. This prayer models ongoing petition for authentic vocations and spiritual leadership throughout the world.
